unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Ensuring Quality, From Factory Floor to Festive Table**
normalised: **Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Ensuring Quality, From Factory Floor to Festive Table**

unnormalised: As demand surges ahead of Onam, manufacturers are doubling down on quality control processes to ensure timely delivery of defect-free products. A recent CII survey highlights that nearly 40% of Indian manufacturers cite inconsistent quality as a major challenge.
normalised: As demand surges ahead of Onam, manufacturers are doubling down on quality control processes to ensure timely delivery of defect-free products. A recent C I I survey highlights that nearly forty percent of Indian manufacturers cite inconsistent quality as a major challenge.

unnormalised: From textiles in Tiruppur to electronics in Bengaluru, robust quality checks are crucial. This involves meticulous inspections at each stage, from raw material sourcing to final packaging. Companies are increasingly adopting Six Sigma methodologies and investing in advanced testing equipment, including those developed by IIT Madras.

unnormalised: Defective biryani spices, for example, could ruin the festive feast for thousands. Similarly, poorly manufactured lights during Diwali can pose serious safety hazards.

unnormalised: "Quality isn't just a cost; it's an investment," says Mr. Sharma, Head of Supply Chain at Tata Steel. "Investing in rigorous quality control saves us Rs. 5 lakhs per month in rework alone." He emphasized that implementing a robust QA system ensures customer satisfaction and strengthens brand reputation, driving long-term growth and consumer trust in "Made in India" products. Every km of a supply chain benefits from robust quality assurance.
